FacilityName: Pilot Chemical Company of Ohio Middletown Plant

_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Sulfur Trioxide/Sulfur Dioxide Sulfonation process consists of two production units interconnected to a common Sulfur Trioxide day tank and a Sulfur Trioxide storage tank.  The Sulfur Trioxide day tank is located inside of a heated and enclosed dike that can contain the entire contents of the tank.  This dike as well as all of the Sulfur Trioxide processing equipment is located inside of a concrete wall and roof process building.  The Sulfur Trioxide storage tank is located inside of a heated building that can contain the entire contents of the tank.  Sulfur Trioxide is received in 2,600 gallon tank trucks which are unloaded in a concrete dike that can contain the entire contents of the tank truck.  The Sulfur Trioxide unloaders undergo an extensive training program and yearly certification is required.



The Sulfur Dioxide storage tanks are located in a covered, outside, concrete dike that can contain the entire contents of one tank.  Sulfur dioxide is received in 3,500 gallon tank trucks which are then unloaded in a concrete dike that can contain the entire contents of the tank truck.  Sulfur Dioxide is unloaded approximately 12 times a year.



Sulfur Dioxide detectors are placed in 9 strategic locations throughout the process building and storage areas.  The detectors activate both visual and audible alarms inside of the control room and a visual alarm inside of the process area.



All processing vessels are designed and tested to ASME codes and fitted with relief systems.  Each relief valve is installed downstream of a rupture disk to effect isolation from the process chemicals.  All positive displacement type pumping systems are fitted with internal or bypass type relief valves.



Both production units are computer controlled utilizing a DCS system with equipment interlocks.  These interlocks prevent inadvertent startups and allow for orderly shutdown in the event of loss of power, instrument air or steam or other process upsets.  All process equipment and valves are designed to shut down to a safe condition.  All critical process parameters utilize alarming routines through the control system that activate both visual and audible alarms in the control room.



An emergency shutdown system stops all transfer pumps, closes all isolation and control valves and sounds an audible alarm thus limiting the amount of a toxic release and alerting personnel of an emergency situation.  The emergency shutdown system can be activated by pressing a conspicuously marked red palm button in any one of three locations in the process building.  Training on the use of the emergency systems occurs at least once a year.



Both production units are registered under International Standard Organization ISO 9001:2008 and are in compliance with the OSHA Process Safety Management standard.  Process and operating procedure changes are processed under a sophisticated Management of Change and Document Control system that assesses the safety, environmental and technical impacts of a process change.



An operator training program is in place that utilizes a combination of classroom training and demonstration of competency with evaluation by written test and observation.  Operators receive training on new and revised operating procedures as well as personal safety and process safety topics.



The mechanical integrity of the process and control equipment, relief systems and instrumentation is maintained by preventive maintenance and equipment calibration programs.

The Sulfur Trioxide vaporizer and Air/Sulfur Trioxide Sulfation equipment is interconnected to the Sulfur Trioxide storage tank.  The Sulfur Trioxide vaporizer and Air/Sulfur Trioxide Sulfation equipment is located inside of a concrete wall and roof process building.  The vaporizer, reactor and Sulfur Trioxide absorber are each situated above concrete pits large enough to contain the entire contents of the largest vessel.

All positive displacement type pumping systems are fitted with internal or bypass type relief valves.

All process equipment and valves are designed to shut down to a safe condition.  All critical process parameters utilize alarming routines through the control system that activates both visual and audible alarms in the control room.

The emergency shutdown system can be activated by pressing a conspicuously marked red palm button in the control room.  Training on the use of the emergency systems occurs at least once a year.

Process and operating procedure changes are processed under a sophisticated Management of Change and Document Control system that assesses the safety, environmental and technical impacts of a process change.

The Isopropylamine and Ethanol storage tanks are located in an outside concrete dike that can contain the entire contents of the tanks.  The storage tanks are designed and tested to ASME codes and fitted with relief systems.  The tanks and all associated piping are grounded.  All manual and actuated valves are fitted with fire-safe, spring-closed actuators.



Isopropylamine and Ethanol are received in 6,000 gallon tank trucks which are then unloaded in an area connected to a concrete dike that can contain the entire contents of the tank truck.



Flammable liquid processing is performed in vessels that are inerted with a nitrogen atmosphere.  The final product is not a flammable substance. _exec_summary.SummaryText:
The mission of Pilot Chemical is to manufacture chemicals in a safe, efficient and environmentally acceptable manner.  Pilot Chemical holds to the ChemStewards environmental, health, safety and security principles as developed by the Society of Chemical Manufacturers and Affiliates (SOCMA).  Pilot Chemical is also committed to the maintenance of a quality management system which meets the requirements of the International Standards Organization ISO 9001:2008.  This commitment requires the work force to focus on the production of a quality product through continuous improvement in all phases of its operations.



The Pilot Chemical Company of Ohio, Middletown Plant occupies 27 acres in an open, relatively flat, combination rural and industrial area, southwest of Middletown, Ohio.  The original facility was constructed in 1984 with building additions in 1995 and 2012 and process additions in 1995 and 1998. The facility produces detergent grade sulfonic acid, synthetic detergents, surfactants and emulsifiers through continuous sulf(on)ation and neutralizer systems for use in the industrial, agricultural and personal care markets.



The regulated substances on site exceeding threshold quantities are Sulfur Dioxide and Sulfur Trioxide, both of which are toxics, and Isopropylamine and Ethanol, both of which are flammable liquids.



Sulfur Dioxide is a clear, water-white liquid at temperatures below its atmospheric-pressure boiling point of

14 deg. F.  Sulfur Dioxide is stored on site as a liquefied, compressed gas at a pressure near 100 psi.  Sulfur

Dioxide vapors are colorless and heavier than air, but are extremely irritating and suffocating at concentrations above 30 ppm. With a distinctive rotten egg smell, Sulfur Dioxide has good warning properties with an odor threshold of 0.5 ppm.  Sulfur Dioxide is stable and non-flammable in either the gaseous or liquid state.



Sulfur Trioxide is a clear, colorless, oily liquid at temperatures between its freezing and boili

ng points, which are 90 deg. F and 113 deg. F, respectively.  Sulfur Trioxide has a strong irritating odor and is very hygroscopic, reacting violently with water.  Sulfur Trioxide fumes react with the moisture in the air to form a dense, white cloud of Sulfuric Acid mist.  This mist is extremely irritating to the eyes, skin and respiratory system.



Isopropylamine is a colorless, water-white, highly flammable liquid with a strong ammonia-like odor.  Isopropylamine evaporates readily evolving vapor that is heavier than air and easily ignited.  Isoproplyamine

is completely soluble in water and will not ignite at a concentration below 25%.



Ethanol is a clear, colorless liquid with an invisible vapor and strong, sweet, alcohol-like odor.  Ethanol is completely miscible in water.  Ethanol has a flash point of 54?F and is considered a Class IB flammable liquid by OSHA and NFPA.  With a lower flammability limit of 3.3%, releases of Ethanol are potential fire hazards.  Ethanol is normally stable, but reacts violently with strong oxidizing agents.



Industries and residences are at least 600 feet from the main building containing the sulfonation processes and from the Sulfur Dioxide and Sulfur Trioxide storage tanks.  The Isopropylamine and Ethanol storage tanks are 400 feet from the nearest industrial area and residence and 200 feet from the process building.



This facility has in place an accidental release prevention program that complies with all of the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management standard.  In addition:

  ▪    Sensitive Sulfur Dioxide and flammable vapor detection systems are installed with monitors located in strategic locations throughout the processing areas to alert plant personnel of leaks.

  ▪    The facility undergoes annual safety inspections by the Middletown Fire Department and our insurance company.

  ▪    Before beginning any maintenance operation involving hot work, a Hot Work permit must be completed and signed by

both production and engineering.

  ▪    The computer controlled processes are "Fail safe" and include emergency shutdown capability that close isolation valves and stop chemical transfers to effectively limit the extent of a release.  Instruments continuously monitor pressure, temperature and level in critical process vessels and automatically alarm if a parameter exceeds acceptable ranges. Equipment interlocking is utilized to prevent operation under unsafe conditions.

  ▪    All manual and automated valves in the Isopropylamine and Ethanol systems have fusible links so that the valves automatically close in the event of a fire.

  ▪    An operator training program is in place that utilizes a combination of classroom training and demonstration of competency with evaluation by written test and observation.  Operators receive training on new and revised operating procedures as well as personal and process safety.

  ▪    All incidents and recognized near-misses are investigated, including very small drips and leaks, and actions are taken to prevent recurrence.

  ▪    A mechanical integrity program is in place which includes equipment preventive maintenance schedules, vessel thickness testing, relief system inspections and instrumentation calibration.

  ▪    Pre-startup reviews are held prior to starting new or modified equipment per OSHA standards.

  ▪    Routine audits of operating procedures and work instructions are conducted to assure that safe practices are followed.

  ▪    Plant security is in place to restrict unauthorized access to the facility and the chemicals of interest.



This facility has had no reportable accidents with off-site consequences within the past 5 years.  In addition, no onsite reportable injuries involving Sulfur Dioxide, Sulfur Trioxide, Isopropylamine, or Ethanol have occurred since startup of the facility in 1984.



Because we believe that in the event of a chemical accident quick response is necessary t

o minimize the likelihood of onsite or offsite injuries, an extensive emergency response plan has been developed.  In addition to the written plan:

  ▪    All employees receive annual training on the use of the emergency response and evacuation plans, use of personal protective equipment, operation of fire extinguishers and spill mitigation techniques.

  ▪    Currently, 22 plant personnel are trained at the 40-hour industrial emergency responder Technician level.  Each technician receives annual refresher training.

  ▪    The facility has a working relationship with the Middletown Fire Department and Butler County Local Emergency Planning Committee.

  ▪    Emergency response drills are performed regularly.

  ▪    Emergency response equipment is on site including a plant wide breathing air system.

  ▪    A plant wide emergency notification system is in place.
